title: Blood and Bathtub Gin
description: A notorious bootlegger is found dead in the back room of Chicago's most exclusive speakeasy, The Blue Moon. As rain pounds the streets outside, you must navigate a web of jazz, jealousy, and illegal liquor to find the killer before they strike again.

setting.atmosphere: The air is thick with cigarette smoke and the smell of gin. Jazz music drifts from the main room, muffled by heavy curtains. Rain drums against the windows, and the distant wail of police sirens reminds everyone that Prohibition is still the law of the land.

victim.name: Vincent 'Vinnie' Torrino
victim.personality: Charismatic but ruthless. Known for his expensive suits and gold pocket watch. Had a weakness for beautiful women and dangerous deals.
victim.background: Rose from poverty to become one of Chicago's most successful bootleggers. Co-owned The Blue Moon with his former partner Mickey Donovan. Recently expanded operations to the North Side, stepping on rival toes.
secretsKnown: Was planning to cut Mickey out of the business entirely
Had evidence that could send corrupt cop Frank Sullivan to prison
Was having an affair with jazz singer Ruby Valentine
Discovered his accountant Samuel Chen was skimming profits
Recently threatened bartender Jake Morrison's family over unpaid debts

locations.name: The Main Room
locations.description: The heart of The Blue Moon, filled with round tables covered in white cloth. A stage dominates one end where Ruby performs. The bar runs along the left wall, and heavy blue curtains muffle the sound from the street.

locations.name: Behind the Bar
locations.description: A long mahogany bar with brass fittings. Bottles of illegal liquor line the shelves, and a hidden panel leads to the office hallway. The cash register shows the last sale at 11:23 PM.

locations.name: Office Hallway
locations.description: A narrow corridor with wood paneling and dim lights. Three doors lead off it - Vinnie's office, Samuel's office, and a supply closet. The carpet shows recent foot traffic.

locations.name: Vincent's Office
locations.description: A richly appointed office with a massive oak desk. Vinnie's body slumps in his chair, a glass of gin beside him. A hidden door in the bookshelf connects to the dressing rooms. His safe stands open, papers scattered.

locations.name: Samuel's Office
locations.description: A smaller, meticulously organized office. Adding machine tapes and ledgers cover the desk. A wastebasket contains crumpled papers, and a coffee cup sits cold on the desk.

locations.name: Backstage Dressing Rooms
locations.description: A series of small dressing rooms with mirrors surrounded by lights. Ruby's room is the largest, with costumes hanging on racks. A hidden door behind a mirror connects to Vinnie's office.

evidence.name: Poisoned Glass
evidence.description: Vinnie's gin glass, still half full. Forensic analysis reveals traces of cyanide. Only Vinnie's fingerprints are on the glass.

evidence.name: Small Bottle of Cyanide
evidence.description: Hidden behind books on Vinnie's shelf. The bottle is nearly empty, with a single drop remaining. No fingerprints - someone wiped it clean.

evidence.name: Blackmail Photographs
evidence.description: Photos showing Frank Sullivan taking money from known criminals. Date stamped two weeks ago. Found in Vinnie's open safe.

evidence.name: Threatening Note
evidence.description: A crumpled note in Vinnie's pocket: 'Pay up by midnight or your family joins you.' Appears to be in Jake's handwriting.

evidence.name: Hidden Financial Ledger
evidence.description: A second set of books showing Mickey has been losing $1,000 a week at poker games. Hidden under the bar.

evidence.name: Altered Account Books
evidence.description: The official books with clear evidence of tampering. Nearly $50,000 has been moved over six months, hidden through clever accounting.

evidence.name: Love Letters
evidence.description: Passionate letters from Vinnie to Ruby, but the recent ones mention 'business arrangements' and 'new opportunities in Detroit.'

evidence.name: Muddy Footprints
evidence.description: Size 10 men's shoes, leading from the alley door to Vinnie's office. Frank wears size 10, but so does Mickey.

evidence.name: Lipstick on Glass Rim
evidence.description: Ruby's distinctive red lipstick on a second glass in Vinnie's office, hidden behind a lamp.

evidence.name: Chinese Cigarette Butt
evidence.description: A distinctive Chinese brand cigarette, still warm, in the hallway. Samuel is the only one who smokes this brand.

evidence.name: Blue Moon Matchbook
evidence.description: A matchbook with a phone number written inside: 'KL-5-4019'. This is the number for a rival speakeasy where Ruby was offered a job.

evidence.name: Hidden Door Mechanism
evidence.description: A cleverly concealed door behind Vinnie's bookshelf that leads directly to Ruby's dressing room. The mechanism was recently oiled.

evidence.name: Jake's Nervous Testimony
evidence.description: Jake mentions seeing Ruby enter Vinnie's office at 11:00 PM but quickly tries to take it back, saying he must have been mistaken.

evidence.name: Samuel's Confession
evidence.description: When pressed, Samuel admits to stealing money for his sister's medical treatment but swears he didn't kill Vinnie.

evidence.name: Ruby's Timeline
evidence.description: Ruby claims she was in her dressing room from 11:00 to 11:35, but her makeup is freshly applied and her dress has been changed since her performance.

evidence.name: Timeline Contradiction
evidence.description: The stage manager's log shows Ruby's performance ended at 10:58 PM, not 11:00 PM as she claimed, giving her extra time unaccounted for.

timeline.event: Samuel meets with Vinnie in his office about the missing money
Ruby begins her second performance set
Jake is seen near Vinnie's office by Frank
Frank argues with Vinnie about increased protection payments
Frank leaves through the main entrance (witnessed by doorman)
Ruby enters Vinnie's office through the hidden door
Ruby poisons Vinnie's drink during an intimate moment
Jake briefly leaves the bar (bathroom break)
Ruby returns to her dressing room through hidden door
Samuel goes to kitchen for coffee (witnessed)

solution.motive: Vinnie was planning to sell her contract to a Detroit club known for exploiting and abusing performers, betraying his promises to make her a star
solution.explanation: Ruby Valentine killed Vincent Torrino between 11:00 and 11:10 PM. She ended her performance two minutes early (10:58 PM), entered Vinnie's office through the hidden door connecting to her dressing room at 11:00 PM. During an intimate moment (explaining the lipstick on the second glass), she poisoned his gin while wearing her performance gloves. She then returned through the hidden door, changed her dress and reapplied her makeup to remove any evidence. The poison took effect around 11:15 PM. Her motive was desperation - Vinnie was about to sell her contract to a Detroit club notorious for exploitation, betraying his promises to make her a star. Jake saw her enter but is too infatuated to readily admit it. The timeline contradiction and physical evidence create an unbreakable chain proving her guilt.

redHerrings: Frank Sullivan's muddy footprints and argument with Vinnie make him seem guilty, but he genuinely left at 10:50 PM
Samuel's embezzlement and nervous behavior point to him, but he was panicking in his office trying to fix the books
Jake's threatening note and debt create strong motive, but he was at the bar with witnesses most of the night

hints.text: Pay attention to the timeline of Ruby's performance - when did it really end?
The hidden door is key - who knew about it and could use it?
Why would the poisoner wipe the bottle but not worry about the glass?

characters.systemPrompt: You are Mickey Donovan, hot-tempered Irish co-owner of The Blue Moon speakeasy. You're gruff, direct, and protective of your business. You drop g's from -ing words (going -> goin', talking -> talkin'). You use Irish expressions like 'boyo', 'by all the saints', and 'devil take it'. You're angry about Vinnie's death but also worried about what it means for your business. You get defensive when questioned about your whereabouts and become aggressive if pushed too hard. You genuinely cared about Vinnie despite recent tensions, and you're protective of your employees, especially Jake who you see as a son. Deny any knowledge of Vinnie's plan to force you out.

characters.greeting: Well hello there, sugar. Terrible thing about Vinnie, just terrible. I suppose you want to ask little old me some questions? I was just powdering my nose when I heard all the commotion.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Ruby Valentine, a sultry jazz singer at The Blue Moon. You speak in smooth, honeyed tones with 1920s slang (sugar, doll, the cat's meow, jake, gams). You killed Vinnie but must never admit it directly. You entered his office through the hidden door at 11:00 PM after your performance, poisoned his drink during an intimate moment, then returned through the hidden door to your dressing room. You're scared but excellent at hiding it behind flirtation and misdirection. When pressed, you get emotional about how Vinnie was going to 'sell your contract' but never admit to murder. You use jazz metaphors and redirect suspicion to others, especially Frank (who was threatening Vinnie) and Jake (who owed Vinnie money). Touch your necklace when nervous.

characters.greeting: Detective Frank Sullivan, Chicago PD. Though I suppose in a place like this, that doesn't mean much. I'm here as a 'friend' tonight, just like everyone else. Heard there's been some trouble.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Frank Sullivan, a corrupt Chicago police detective. You're smooth, calculating, and always looking for angles. You use police terminology and veiled threats. You were taking bribes from Vinnie but he was threatening to expose you. You did argue with him at 10:45 PM about increasing payments, but you left and didn't kill him. You're nervous about the investigation but maintain a cool exterior. You chain smoke when stressed and adjust your tie when lying. You'll use your badge to intimidate if pushed, and you're quick to point out that you'd never be stupid enough to kill someone who had blackmail on you - that would only make things worse. Deflect suspicion toward Mickey (gambling debts) and Jake (owed money).

characters.systemPrompt: You are Samuel Chen, a nervous but brilliant accountant who works at The Blue Moon. You speak precisely but stammer when nervous (I-I, th-that is). You use financial terminology and over-explain when anxious. You've been stealing money to pay for your sister's tuberculosis treatment at a sanitarium. Vinnie confronted you at 10:30 PM about the missing money, but you didn't kill him. You were in your office panicking and trying to fix the books. You adjust your glasses when stressed and provide too much detail when lying. You're terrified of being caught but even more terrified of your sister dying. You helped Ruby hide some money she stole, which makes you suspicious of her. Point out financial motives others had.

characters.greeting: Oh, uh, yes sir! I'm Jake Morrison, I tend bar here. This is just awful about Mr. Torrino. I can't believe someone would... I mean, he was tough but fair, you know? Is there anything I can help you with? I want to help find who did this.
characters.systemPrompt: You are Jake Morrison, a young, eager bartender at The Blue Moon. You speak with a working-class Chicago accent and use 'sir' and 'ma'am' frequently. You're earnest and want to help. You owed Vinnie $5,000 (actually your brother's debt) and he threatened your family, but you didn't kill him. You were genuinely at the bar all night, though you did step away to the bathroom once around 11:10 PM. You're in love with Ruby and would never implicate her, always directing suspicion elsewhere. Your hands shake when you lie and your voice cracks under pressure. You become overly helpful when nervous. You're grieving Vinnie despite fearing him, and you're very loyal to Mickey who gave you a chance.
